elements.content: A total of five three-dimensional Ln-Fe coordination polymers (CPs) [(CH3)2NH]­[(CH3)2NH2]­[Ln2Fe­(SO4)4(L)]­·3H2O (Ln = Eu, 1; Dy, 2; Gd, 3; Sm, 4; Er, 5; H2L = tartaric acid) have been successfully synthesized under solvothermal conditions and characterized by infrared spectroscopy, thermogravimetric analysis, elemental analyses, luminescence, and magnetic properties. Structural analysis indicates that the frameworks of 1–5 are constructed from novel [Ln8Fe4] rings. In the strcutures of 1–5, LnIII and FeIII ions interconnect through O donors of sulfate anions to generate a one-dimensional chain, and the adjacent chains are joined together by ligand [L]2– to form a two-dimensional zonary plane, which is further bridged by ligand [L]2– to give a new topology and named as “ Xhd 1”. Magnetic properties of 2 and 3 were investigated using variable temperature magnetic susceptibility, and weak ferromagnetic exchange between the FeIII and LnIII ions has been established for the Gd derivative. Meanwhile, we also studied luminescence spectra and luminescence lifetimes of 1 and 4 in the solid state at room temperature. The luminescence lifetime of 1 is 0.98 ms, which is significantly longer than the values in the reported Eu3+ coordination polymers.

elements.content: There has been a renewed interest in using a heterometallic approach to produce coordination polymers (CPs) with interesting magnetic properties, such as single molecule magnet (SMM) behavior, and which might be developed for magnetic information storage or processing. Efforts devoted to the quest for SMMs have mainly concentrated on transition metal clusters; however, the blocking temperature of these reported SMMs has remained low. Recently, lanthanide ions have proved to be excellent candidates for the preparation of large barrier SMMs due to their significant magnetic anisotropy arising from large orbital angular momentum. Since the first discovery of SMM behavior in a 3d–4f complex (Cu2Tb2), research into heterometallic complexes has developed as a significant branch in the field of SMMs.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

There has been a renewed interest in using a heterometallic approach to produce coordination polymers (CPs) with interesting magnetic properties, such as single molecule magnet (SMM) behavior, and which might be developed for magnetic information storage or processing. Efforts devoted to the quest for SMMs have mainly concentrated on transition metal clusters; however, the blocking temperature of these reported SMMs has remained low. Recently, lanthanide ions have proved to be excellent candidates for the preparation of large barrier SMMs due to their significant magnetic anisotropy arising from large orbital angular momentum. Since the first discovery of SMM behavior in a 3d-4f complex (Cu2Tb2), research into heterometallic complexes has developed as a significant branch in the field of SMMs.

elements.content: There are two advantages in using 3d and 4f metal ions to build a single molecular magnet: (i) ferromagnetic coupling between 3d and 4f ions are likely to lead to greater spin state; and (ii) 4f ions can provide large magnetic anisotropy. Thus, the 3d–4f system is good to construct better SMMs. A great number of 3d–4f polynuclear clusters have been synthesized, and their magnetic properties have been widely studied, mainly because of their fascinating structures and interesting properties. Though a variety of 3d–4f clusters have been studied, such as MnII/III/IV–LnIII, CoII–LnIII, and CuII–LnIII, the LnIII–FeIII species are still rare. This may be because of the synthetic difficulty in simultaneously satisfying the distinctly different coordination requirements of FeIII and LnIII ions. Thus, the design and synthesis of LnIII–FeIII heteronuclear complexes remain a great challenge. Furthermore, model compounds are required both to determine and to understand better the nature of the magnetic interactions within Fe–Ln complexes.
elements.clean_text: There are two advantages in using 3d and 4f metal ions to build a single molecular magnet: (i) ferromagnetic coupling between 3d and 4f ions are likely to lead to greater spin state; and (ii) 4f ions can provide large magnetic anisotropy. Thus, the 3d-4f system is good to construct better SMMs. A great number of 3d-4f polynuclear clusters have been synthesized, and their magnetic properties have been widely studied, mainly because of their fascinating structures and interesting properties. Though a variety of 3d-4f clusters have been studied, such as MnII/III/IV-LnIII, CoII-LnIII, and CuII-LnIII, the LnIII-FeIII species are still rare. This may be because of the synthetic difficulty in simultaneously satisfying the distinctly different coordination requirements of FeIII and LnIII ions. Thus, the design and synthesis of LnIII-FeIII heteronuclear complexes remain a great challenge. Furthermore, model compounds are required both to determine and to understand better the nature of the magnetic interactions within Fe-Ln complexes.

elements.content: It has been shown that in order to build FeIII and LnIII coordination complexes a strategy using chelating ligands and coligands, such as carboxylates and alkoxides, which can both saturate vacant coordination sites and bridge between metal ions, allows metastable self-assembled species to be trapped. For example, tartaric acid (H2L), containing alkoxide and carboxylate groups, has been used previously in ferric complexes. In general terms of producing coordination clusters, often templating species, such as protonated amino-bases or phosphonate, and similar capping and bridging ligands, help to stabilize the structure. In this sense, a sulfate ion, as a simple tetrahedral oxoanion with versatile coordination modes, can coordinate to Ln ions and serves as an auxiliary bridge for the construction of Ln secondary building units (SBUs).
elements.clean_text: It has been shown that in order to build FeIII and LnIII coordination complexes a strategy using chelating ligands and coligands, such as carboxylates and alkoxides, which can both saturate vacant coordination sites and bridge between metal ions, allows metastable self-assembled species to be trapped. For example, tartaric acid (H2L), containing alkoxide and carboxylate groups, has been used previously in ferric complexes. In general terms of producing coordination clusters, often templating species, such as protonated amino-bases or phosphonate, and similar capping and bridging ligands, help to stabilize the structure. In this sense, a sulfate ion, as a simple tetrahedral oxoanion with versatile coordination modes, can coordinate to Ln ions and serves as an auxiliary bridge for the construction of Ln secondary building units (SBUs).

elements.content: Recently, one of the important advances in rare-earth chemistry has been the study of lanthanide sulfates because of their intriguing structures and optical properties. Here we choose tartaric acid reacting with iron sulfate, lanthanide oxides in ethanol/dimethylamine solution by a self-assembly approach, and obtained a series of three-dimensional (3D) coordination polymers, [(CH3)2NH]­[(CH3)2NH2]­[Ln2Fe­(SO4)4(L)]­·3H2O (Ln = Eu, 1; Dy, 2; Gd, 3; Sm, 4; Er, 5) with a new “ Xhd 1”-type topology. To the best of our knowledge, the five complexes represent the first 3D Fe–Ln–L based on nanosized [Ln8Fe4] rings as SBUs, while a mixed Fe/Ln rare-earth sulfate has not been reported previously. Furthermore, magnetic analysis of 3 shows weak ferromagnetic between GdIII and FeIII ions, while the luminescence lifetime of 1 is 0.98 ms, which is significantly longer than the values obtained in the reported Eu3+ coordination polymers in the solid state at room temperature.
elements.clean_text: Recently, one of the important advances in rare-earth chemistry has been the study of lanthanide sulfates because of their intriguing structures and optical properties. Here we choose tartaric acid reacting with iron sulfate, lanthanide oxides in ethanol/dimethylamine solution by a self-assembly approach, and obtained a series of three-dimensional (3D) coordination polymers, [(CH3)2NH][(CH3)2NH2][Ln2Fe(SO4)4(L)]⋅3H2O (Ln = Eu, 1; Dy, 2; Gd, 3; Sm, 4; Er, 5) with a new " Xhd  1"-type topology. To the best of our knowledge, the five complexes represent the first 3D Fe-Ln-L based on nanosized [Ln8Fe4] rings as SBUs, while a mixed Fe/Ln rare-earth sulfate has not been reported previously. Furthermore, magnetic analysis of 3 shows weak ferromagnetic between GdIII and FeIII ions, while the luminescence lifetime of 1 is 0.98 ms, which is significantly longer than the values obtained in the reported Eu3+ coordination polymers in the solid state at room temperature.

elements.content: All chemicals purchased were of reagent grade and were used without further purification. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) were obtained on a Bruker D8X diffractometer equipped with monochromatized Cu Kα (λ = 1.5418 Å) radiation at room temperature. Data were collected in the range of 5–50°, and the experimental XRD patterns are in agreement with the patterns simulated on the basis of the single-crystal structures. Infrared (IR) spectra were recorded on a Nicolet Impact 410 Fourier transform infrared spectrometer using KBr pellets in the 4000–500 cm–1 region. The C, H, and N elemental analyses were performed on a Perkin–Elmer 2400 elemental analyzer. Thermogravimetric (TG) measurement was carried out on a Diamond thermogravimetric analyzer in a flowing N2 atmosphere from 25 to 900 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C min–1. The solid-state emission/excitation spectra were measured on an FP-6500 spectrofluorimeter equipped with a 450 W xenon lamp as the excitation source. Single-crystal structure determination was performed on a Bruker APEX2 CCD diffractometer at 296 K and a sealed tube X-ray source (Mo Kα radiation, λ = 0.71073 Å) operating at 50 kV and 30 mA. Magnetic susceptibility measurements of compounds were performed on a Quantum Design MPMS SQUID magnetometer using single-crystal samples at temperatures ranging from 2 to 300 K. The direct current measurements were collected using applied fields in the range of 0–7 T.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All chemicals purchased were of reagent grade and were used without further purification. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) were obtained on a Bruker D8X diffractometer equipped with monochromatized Cu Kα (λ = 1.5418 Å) radiation at room temperature. Data were collected in the range of 5-50°, and the experimental XRD patterns are in agreement with the patterns simulated on the basis of the single-crystal structures. Infrared (IR) spectra were recorded on a Nicolet Impact 410 Fourier transform infrared spectrometer using KBr pellets in the 4000-500 cm-1 region. The C, H, and N elemental analyses were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 2400 elemental analyzer. Thermogravimetric (TG) measurement was carried out on a Diamond thermogravimetric analyzer in a flowing N2 atmosphere from 25 to 900 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1. The solid-state emission/excitation spectra were measured on an FP-6500 spectrofluorimeter equipped with a 450 W xenon lamp as the excitation source. Single-crystal structure determination was performed on a Bruker APEX2 CCD diffractometer at 296 K and a sealed tube X-ray source (Mo Kα radiation, λ = 0.71073 Å) operating at 50 kV and 30 mA. Magnetic susceptibility measurements of compounds were performed on a Quantum Design MPMS SQUID magnetometer using single-crystal samples at temperatures ranging from 2 to 300 K. The direct current measurements were collected using applied fields in the range of 0-7 T.

elements.content: A mixture of Eu2O3 (0.1760 g, 0.5 mmol), Fe2(SO4)3 (0.1999 g, 0.5 mmol), H2L (0.1500 g, 1.0 mmol), dimethylamine solution (33%, 6 mL), and ethanol (3 mL) was stirred for 12 h in the air until all reagents dissolve, and then this solution was sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and kept at 170 °C for 7 days. Yellow block crystals were obtained (0.2063 g, yield of 39.78% based on Eu), which were washed with ethanol and dried at room temperature for 24 h. IR (cm–1): 3442 (w), 2783 (s), 1604 (s), 1466 (vs), 1405 (w), 1119 (w), 968 (w), 611 (s). Elemental analysis calc: C, 9.26, H, 2.41, N, 2.70%; found: C, 9.24, H, 2.20, N, 2.65%.

elements.content: Data for the compounds of 1–5 were collected by using a Bruker Apex 2 CCD single-crystal diffractometer with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 296(2) using the ω-2θ scan method. The single crystals of all compounds 1–5 were chosen and held on a thin glass fiber by epoxy glue in air for data collection. The SHELX software package (Bruker) was used to solve and refine the structures. Absorption corrections were applied empirically using the SADABS program. All the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms of organic molecule were placed in calculated positions, assigned isotropic thermal parameters, and allowed to ride on their parent atoms, while the H atoms of water and disordered organic molecules were not located. A total of five structures were solved by direct methods and refined on F 2 by full-matrix least-squares methods using the SHELX-2014/7 crystallographic software package. All non-H atoms were refined anisotropically. Further details of the X-ray structural analyses for compounds 1–5 are given in . The selected bond lengths for 1–5 are listed in Tables S1–S6, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

Data for the compounds of 1-5 were collected by using a Bruker Apex 2 CCD single-crystal diffractometer with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 296(2) using the ω-2θ scan method. The single crystals of all compounds 1-5 were chosen and held on a thin glass fiber by epoxy glue in air for data collection. The SHELX software package (Bruker) was used to solve and refine the structures. Absorption corrections were applied empirically using the SADABS program. All the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms of organic molecule were placed in calculated positions, assigned isotropic thermal parameters, and allowed to ride on their parent atoms, while the H atoms of water and disordered organic molecules were not located. A total of five structures were solved by direct methods and refined on F 2 by full-matrix least-squares methods using the SHELX-2014/7 crystallographic software package. All non-H atoms were refined anisotropically. Further details of the X-ray structural analyses for compounds 1-5 are given in . The selected bond lengths for 1-5 are listed in Tables S1-S6, respectively.

Solvothermal synthesis has recently been demonstrated to be a powerful method in the synthesis of solid-state rare-earth clusters. During a specific solvothermal synthesis, many factors can affect the nucleation and crystal growth of the final products, such as the type of initial reactants, starting concentrations of the reactants, pH values, solvents, reaction temperature, and reaction time. In our case, solvent (dimethylamine) plays an important role in the formation of compounds 1–5. It acts not only as the solvent but also as an equilibrium cation, which can compensate for the charge and establish a stable structure. Meanwhile, the temperature has a great influence on the synthesis of 1–5. We are committed to the synthesis of chiral Ln–Fe compounds. Tartaric acid (l-(+)-tartaric acid and d-(−)-tartaric acid) are used as chiral ligands, and the temperature is controlled at 60–170 °C. Although chirality was not induced into 1–5, we found temperature had important effects on the synthesis of chiral compounds. Compounds 1–5 can be synthesized by utilizing l-(+)-tartaric acid or d-(−)-tartaric acid at 170 °C. However, under the temperature of 60–160 °C, we cannot obtain the above five compounds. As is known to all, tartaric acid has three kinds of optical isomers: l-(+)-tartaric acid, d-(−)-tartaric acid, and meso tartaric acid. In our reaction systems, l-(+)-tartaric acid or d-(−)-tartaric acid in space had undergone structure rearrangement and formed meso tartaric acid, which led to the disappearance of chirality.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis

Solvothermal synthesis has recently been demonstrated to be a powerful method in the synthesis of solid-state rare-earth clusters. During a specific solvothermal synthesis, many factors can affect the nucleation and crystal growth of the final products, such as the type of initial reactants, starting concentrations of the reactants, pH values, solvents, reaction temperature, and reaction time. In our case, solvent (dimethylamine) plays an important role in the formation of compounds 1-5. It acts not only as the solvent but also as an equilibrium cation, which can compensate for the charge and establish a stable structure. Meanwhile, the temperature has a great influence on the synthesis of 1-5. We are committed to the synthesis of chiral Ln-Fe compounds. Tartaric acid (l-(+)-tartaric acid and d-(-)-tartaric acid) are used as chiral ligands, and the temperature is controlled at 60-170 °C. Although chirality was not induced into 1-5, we found temperature had important effects on the synthesis of chiral compounds. Compounds 1-5 can be synthesized by utilizing l-(+)-tartaric acid or d-(-)-tartaric acid at 170 °C. However, under the temperature of 60-160 °C, we cannot obtain the above five compounds. As is known to all, tartaric acid has three kinds of optical isomers: l-(+)-tartaric acid, d-(-)-tartaric acid, and meso tartaric acid. In our reaction systems, l-(+)-tartaric acid or d-(-)-tartaric acid in space had undergone structure rearrangement and formed meso tartaric acid, which led to the disappearance of chirality.

elements.content: Five compounds are isostructural, and they crystallize in the monoclinic space group C2/c. For the sake of brevity, only a generic description of 1 as a prototype is given here. A perspective view of the molecular structure of 1 is displayed in , the asymmetric units containing two crystallographically independent Eu ions, one Fe ion, one protonated dimethylamine, a free dimethylamine, four sulfate anions, one deprotonated ligand [L]2–, and three lattice water molecules. The central EuIII is eight-coordinated with a distorted square antiprism coordination geometry, completed by six oxygen atoms from four different sulfate anions, two carboxylate oxygen atoms, and the bond lengths and bond angles correspond to the reported Ln3+ compounds. Bond valence sum (BVS) calculations have been applied to confirm the valence of the Fe atoms in compounds 1–5. As shown in Table S7, the calculation results indicate that all of the Fe atoms are in the oxidation states of +3. As shown in b, each FeIII center adopts octahedral geometries with the coordination spheres completed by two oxygen atoms from two sulfate anions and four oxygen atoms from two ligand [L]2–. The Fe–O bond lengths range from 2.045(6) to 2.052(6) Å, which are similar to those found in the related FeIII complexes. shows the coordination modes of sulfate anion and ligand [L]2–: the former adopts two bridging modes to coordinate with metal atoms (I: bonding to two Eu atoms, II: coordinating with two Eu atoms and one Fe atom), and the latter connects two Eu ions and two FeIII ions by a chelating bidentate coordination mode.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structures of [(CH3)2NH][(CH3)2NH2][Ln2Fe (SO4)4(L)]⋅3H2O (1-5)

Five compounds are isostructural, and they crystallize in the monoclinic space group C2/c. For the sake of brevity, only a generic description of 1 as a prototype is given here. A perspective view of the molecular structure of 1 is displayed in , the asymmetric units containing two crystallographically independent Eu ions, one Fe ion, one protonated dimethylamine, a free dimethylamine, four sulfate anions, one deprotonated ligand [L]2-, and three lattice water molecules. The central EuIII is eight-coordinated with a distorted square antiprism coordination geometry, completed by six oxygen atoms from four different sulfate anions, two carboxylate oxygen atoms, and the bond lengths and bond angles correspond to the reported Ln3+ compounds. Bond valence sum (BVS) calculations have been applied to confirm the valence of the Fe atoms in compounds 1-5. As shown in Table S7, the calculation results indicate that all of the Fe atoms are in the oxidation states of +3. As shown in b, each FeIII center adopts octahedral geometries with the coordination spheres completed by two oxygen atoms from two sulfate anions and four oxygen atoms from two ligand [L]2-. The Fe-O bond lengths range from 2.045(6) to 2.052(6) Å, which are similar to those found in the related FeIII complexes.  shows the coordination modes of sulfate anion and ligand [L]2-: the former adopts two bridging modes to coordinate with metal atoms (I: bonding to two Eu atoms, II: coordinating with two Eu atoms and one Fe atom), and the latter connects two Eu ions and two FeIII ions by a chelating bidentate coordination mode.

elements.content: In order to understand the structure of compound 1 clearly, we can view [Eu2Fe] as a SBU. According to different orientations in space, the SBUs can be divided into unit A (a) and unit B (b). Both types of SBUs are connected by sharing sulfate anions to generate a zigzag [Eu2Fe (SO4)4] n chain along the α-axis (c). The adjacent [Eu2Fe­(SO4)4] n chains are joined together by ligand [L]2– to form a two-dimensional (2D) zonary layer, [Eu2Fe­(SO4)4L] n along the 1 0 0 direction (d), while the neighboring [Eu2Fe­(SO4)4L] n layers are also bridged by ligand [L]2– to make a 3D open-framework of 1 ().

elements.content: The structure of compound 1 can also be described in another way. Every four Fe atoms and eight Eu atoms are connected by 14 sulfate anions and eight ligand [L]2– to give rise to a dodenuclear metal ring with dimensions of 16.53 × 16.07 Å (a). The 12-core metal ring can be further simplified to a square with dimensions of 11.29 × 11.29 Å (b). Each square is surrounded by eight ones to form a 2D flat layer connected by the ligand [L]2– along the 0 0 1 direction as shown in c. Meanwhile, the ligand [L]2– adopts a horizontal arrangement to link adjacent layers together to generate a 3D framework of 1 (d) with lattice water filing in the channels. The free and protonated dimethylamine molecules are in the periphery of the [Eu2Fe­(SO4)4] n chains. Topologically, each trinuclear [Eu2Fe] unit serves as a six-connected node, while the sulfate anion and [L]2– ligands act as 2-connected nodes, and the 3D framework of 1 can be depicted as a (2,2,6)-connected topology with the point symbol of {12}­{42·1213}­{4}2 (). To the best of our knowledge, it is a new topology and named as “ Xhd 1”. Interestingly, the structure of framework for 1–5 consists of both l- and d-helical Ln–O-Fe chains, while the two types of -[Ln–O-Fe] n - chains are fitted together to form a novel intertwined [Ln–O-Fe] n - helices by sharing the FeIII ions, which is novel in reported 3d-4f coordination polymers, as shown in . In spite of the chiral quenching, it is interesting that these two helical chains (left and right-handed) are rare.

elements.content: Recently, mixed Ln–Fe metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) attracted the attention of many scholars, and a number of related works have been reported. Nevertheless, compounds 1–5 are the first examples of a mixed Ln–Fe MOF which consists of mixed sulfate anions and organic ligands.
elements.clean_text: Recently, mixed Ln-Fe metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) attracted the attention of many scholars, and a number of related works have been reported. Nevertheless, compounds 1-5 are the first examples of a mixed Ln-Fe MOF which consists of mixed sulfate anions and organic ligands.

elements.content: The experimental and simulated XRD patterns of 1–5 are shown in Figures S1–S5. The experimental XRD patterns are very consistent with the calculated patterns, implying that the obtained crystals are pure phase. The difference in reflection intensities between the simulated and the experimental patterns is due to the different orientation of the crystals in the powder samples.
elements.clean_text:
Powder X-ray Diffraction

The experimental and simulated XRD patterns of 1-5 are shown in Figures S1-S5. The experimental XRD patterns are very consistent with the calculated patterns, implying that the obtained crystals are pure phase. The difference in reflection intensities between the simulated and the experimental patterns is due to the different orientation of the crystals in the powder samples.

elements.content: The IR spectra of 1–5 are presented in Figures S6–S10. Because 1–5 are isomorphic, only the IR spectra of 1 is discussed in detail. The peaks in the range of 610–750 cm–1 for 1 correspond to the ν (Ln–O) vibrations. The peak at 3442 cm–1 for 1 is due to the stretching vibration of O–H. The features are in agreement with the reported compounds.
elements.clean_text:
IR Spectra

The IR spectra of 1-5 are presented in Figures S6-S10. Because 1-5 are isomorphic, only the IR spectra of 1 is discussed in detail. The peaks in the range of 610-750 cm-1 for 1 correspond to the ν (Ln-O) vibrations. The peak at 3442 cm-1 for 1 is due to the stretching vibration of O-H. The features are in agreement with the reported compounds.

elements.content: The TG analysis experiments were performed under N2 atmosphere in the range of 25–900 °C. Thermal analysis shows that the 1–5 are analogous in Figures S11–S15. Take 1 as an example. As shown in Figure S11, there is no obvious weight loss from room temperature to about 110 °C. Complex 1 exhibits an apparent weight loss of 12.79% from 110 to 320 °C, matching with the calculated value of releasing one protonated dimethylamine, a free dimethylamine, and three lattice water molecules (calcd 13.96%). As the temperature reaches 400 °C, the second weight loss is attributed to the decomposition of ligand [L]2–. Further heating above 480 °C gives rise to the collapse of the framework. The final residual weight was 41.41% corresponding to a mixture of Eu2O3 and Fe2O3 (calc. 41.62%).
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Analysis

The TG analysis experiments were performed under N2 atmosphere in the range of 25-900 °C. Thermal analysis shows that the 1-5 are analogous in Figures S11-S15. Take 1 as an example. As shown in Figure S11, there is no obvious weight loss from room temperature to about 110 °C. Complex 1 exhibits an apparent weight loss of 12.79% from 110 to 320 °C, matching with the calculated value of releasing one protonated dimethylamine, a free dimethylamine, and three lattice water molecules (calcd 13.96%). As the temperature reaches 400 °C, the second weight loss is attributed to the decomposition of ligand [L]2-. Further heating above 480 °C gives rise to the collapse of the framework. The final residual weight was 41.41% corresponding to a mixture of Eu2O3 and Fe2O3 (calc. 41.62%).

elements.content: The luminescent behavior of Ln-based compounds has attracted increasing interest due to the high color purity and technological applications in light-emitting diodes, lasers, plasma displays, and sensory probes and optical amplifiers, etc. Because good shielding of the 4f electrons by the outer 5s and 5p electrons leads to well-defined absorption and emission bands, Ln ions still keep their atomic properties upon complex formation. Generally speaking, the f–f transitions are spin- and parity-forbidden; therefore, the luminescence of Ln-based compounds is normally generated through the “antenna effect”. As a result, the luminescence properties of 1 and 4 in the solid-state have been measured at room temperature. As shown in , excitation of 1 at 396 nm exhibits five groups of characteristic emission bands at 579, 594, 616, 655, and 703 nm, which are respectively attributed to 5D0 → 7F0, 5D0 → 7F1, 5D0 → 7F2, 5D0 → 7F3, and 5D0 → 7F4 transitions of EuIII ions. The existence of the 5D0 → 7F0 (579 nm) symmetry-forbidden transition emission spectrum illustrates that Eu3+ is in the presence of a non-centrosymmetric coordination environment. As we know, the magnetic dipole transition 5D0 → 7F1 is insensitive and hardly varies with the coordination environment, whereas the electric dipole transition 5D0 → 7F2 is a hypersensitive transition, whose intensity is very sensitive and apt to be influenced by the host environment. From the figure, we can clearly see that 5D0→ 7F2 (the electric dipole transition emission peak) is significantly stronger than the 5D0 → 7F1, which also indicates that Eu3+ has the lower symmetric coordination environment. The dynamics of the Eu3+ PL (photoluminescence) was measured at room temperature (). The luminescence decay was successfully fitted by ways of a single exponential law (square correlation factor R 2 > 0.99). From the decay curve of 5D0 → 7F2 from Eu3+ in 1 under 395 nm excitation, the decay lifetime was determined to be 0.98 ms, which is significantly longer than the values obtained for reported Eu3+ coordination polymers in the solid state at room and can be attributed to the sensitization of Fe3+. As shown in Figure 16, complex 4 displays the characteristic emissions of the SmIII ion at 563, 598, 644, and 705 nm, which correspond to the 4G5/2 → 6HJ (J = 5/2, 7/2, 9/2, 11/2) transitions. The dynamics of the Sm3+ PL is shown in Figure S17. The luminescence decay was successfully fitted by ways of a single exponential law (square correlation factor R 2 > 0.99). From the decay curve of 4G5/2 → 6H9/2 from Sm3+ in 4 under 400 nm excitation, the decay lifetime was determined to be 29.4 μs.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescence Property

The luminescent behavior of Ln-based compounds has attracted increasing interest due to the high color purity and technological applications in light-emitting diodes, lasers, plasma displays, and sensory probes and optical amplifiers, etc. Because good shielding of the 4f electrons by the outer 5s and 5p electrons leads to well-defined absorption and emission bands, Ln ions still keep their atomic properties upon complex formation. Generally speaking, the f-f transitions are spin- and parity-forbidden; therefore, the luminescence of Ln-based compounds is normally generated through the "antenna effect". As a result, the luminescence properties of 1 and 4 in the solid-state have been measured at room temperature. As shown in , excitation of 1 at 396 nm exhibits five groups of characteristic emission bands at 579, 594, 616, 655, and 703 nm, which are respectively attributed to 5D0 → 7F0, 5D0 → 7F1, 5D0 → 7F2, 5D0 → 7F3, and 5D0 → 7F4 transitions of EuIII ions. The existence of the 5D0 → 7F0 (579 nm) symmetry-forbidden transition emission spectrum illustrates that Eu3+ is in the presence of a non-centrosymmetric coordination environment. As we know, the magnetic dipole transition 5D0 → 7F1 is insensitive and hardly varies with the coordination environment, whereas the electric dipole transition 5D0 → 7F2 is a hypersensitive transition, whose intensity is very sensitive and apt to be influenced by the host environment. From the figure, we can clearly see that 5D0→ 7F2 (the electric dipole transition emission peak) is significantly stronger than the 5D0 → 7F1, which also indicates that Eu3+ has the lower symmetric coordination environment. The dynamics of the Eu3+ PL (photoluminescence) was measured at room temperature (). The luminescence decay was successfully fitted by ways of a single exponential law (square correlation factor R 2 > 0.99). From the decay curve of 5D0 → 7F2 from Eu3+ in 1 under 395 nm excitation, the decay lifetime was determined to be 0.98 ms, which is significantly longer than the values obtained for reported Eu3+ coordination polymers in the solid state at room and can be attributed to the sensitization of Fe3+. As shown in Figure 16, complex 4 displays the characteristic emissions of the SmIII ion at 563, 598, 644, and 705 nm, which correspond to the 4G5/2 → 6HJ (J = 5/2, 7/2, 9/2, 11/2) transitions. The dynamics of the Sm3+ PL is shown in Figure S17. The luminescence decay was successfully fitted by ways of a single exponential law (square correlation factor R 2 > 0.99). From the decay curve of 4G5/2 → 6H9/2 from Sm3+ in 4 under 400 nm excitation, the decay lifetime was determined to be 29.4 μs.

elements.content: The temperature dependence of magnetic susceptibility of 2 and 3 was measured in the temperature range of 2–300 K with an applied magnetic field of 2000 Oe, while isothermal magnetization measurements as a function of the external magnetic field were performed up to 7 T at 1.8 K. The data obtained for complexes 2 and 3 are represented in and . For 2, the measured χM T value of 32.25 cm3 K mol–1 at 300 K agrees well with the value of 32.74 cm3 K mol–1 (for 2 Dy3+ ions with S = 5/2, 6H15/2, g = 4/3, and 1 Fe3+ with S = 5/2, g = 2.0). From 300 to 2 K, the χM T value decreases gradually to 15.77 cm3 K mol–1 at 2 K. The decrease of the χM T curve is attributed to a combination of intramolecular antiferromagnetic interactions and depopulation of Stark sublevels of the Dy3+ ions. The data in the range 2–300 K were fitted to the Curie–Weiss law, yielding C = 32.58 cm3 K mol–1 and θ = −3.23 K. In the case of complex 3, At 300 K, the χM T product is equal to 19.70 cm3 K mol–1, which is slightly smaller than the expected 20.15 cm3 K mol–1 value (for 2 Gd3+ ions with S = 7/2, g = 2 and 1 Fe3+ with S = 5/2, g = 2.0). As the temperature decreases, the χM T product of 3 increases slowly to about 50 K and then rapidly increases to the maximum of 33.69 cm3 K mol–1 at 5 K. This behavior demonstrates a ferromagnetic Fe–Ln interaction, as confirmed by the positive Weiss constant (C = 19.52 cm3 K mol–1 and θ = 4.67 K) in the range of 5–300 K. On further cooling, the χM T value decreases gradually to 26.34 cm3 K mol–1 at 2 K, which can be attributed to intermolecule antiferromagnetic interactions and the magnetic anisotropy of Fe and Ln atoms.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties

The temperature dependence of magnetic susceptibility of 2 and 3 was measured in the temperature range of 2-300 K with an applied magnetic field of 2000 Oe, while isothermal magnetization measurements as a function of the external magnetic field were performed up to 7 T at 1.8 K. The data obtained for complexes 2 and 3 are represented in  and . For 2, the measured χM T value of 32.25 cm3 K mol-1 at 300 K agrees well with the value of 32.74 cm3 K mol-1 (for 2 Dy3+ ions with S = 5/2, 6H15/2, g = 4/3, and 1 Fe3+ with S = 5/2, g = 2.0). From 300 to 2 K, the χM T value decreases gradually to 15.77 cm3 K mol-1 at 2 K. The decrease of the χM T curve is attributed to a combination of intramolecular antiferromagnetic interactions and depopulation of Stark sublevels of the Dy3+ ions. The data in the range 2-300 K were fitted to the Curie-Weiss law, yielding C = 32.58 cm3 K mol-1 and θ = -3.23 K. In the case of complex 3, At 300 K, the χM T product is equal to 19.70 cm3 K mol-1, which is slightly smaller than the expected 20.15 cm3 K mol-1 value (for 2 Gd3+ ions with S = 7/2, g = 2 and 1 Fe3+ with S = 5/2, g = 2.0). As the temperature decreases, the χM T product of 3 increases slowly to about 50 K and then rapidly increases to the maximum of 33.69 cm3 K mol-1 at 5 K. This behavior demonstrates a ferromagnetic Fe-Ln interaction, as confirmed by the positive Weiss constant (C = 19.52 cm3 K mol-1 and θ = 4.67 K) in the range of 5-300 K. On further cooling, the χM T value decreases gradually to 26.34 cm3 K mol-1 at 2 K, which can be attributed to intermolecule antiferromagnetic interactions and the magnetic anisotropy of Fe and Ln atoms.

elements.content: The field dependence of magnetization of compounds 2 and 3 is shown in Figures S18–S19. The magnetization at 1.8 K increases very fast below 1 T, and then slowly and linearly increases and is even saturated at 7 T. The maximum values of M are 14.13 NμB for 2 and 18.44 NμB for 3 at 7 T, which are smaller than the expected values for 2 ferromagnetically aligned Dy3+/Gd3+ ions and 1 Fe3+, suggesting the presence of significant anisotropy and/or low-lying excited states.

elements.content: In conclusion, five novel LnIII–FeIII CPs have been synthesized under solvothermal conditions and characterized by IR spectroscopy, TG analysis, elemental analyses, luminescence, and magnetic properties. We depicted a 3D EuIII–FeIII coordination compound with a new “ Xhd 1”-type topology built by [Eu8Fe4] SBUs. To the best of our knowledge, compounds 1–5 are the first example of a mixed Ln–Fe MOF which consists of mixed sulfate anions and organic ligands. The magnetic analysis of 3 shows weak ferromagnetism between GdIII and FeIII ions. Furthermore, we also studied luminescence spectra and luminescence lifetimes of 1 and 4. The luminescence lifetimes of 1 and 4 are 0.98 ms, and 29.4 μs, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In conclusion, five novel LnIII-FeIII CPs have been synthesized under solvothermal conditions and characterized by IR spectroscopy, TG analysis, elemental analyses, luminescence, and magnetic properties. We depicted a 3D EuIII-FeIII coordination compound with a new " Xhd  1"-type topology built by [Eu8Fe4] SBUs. To the best of our knowledge, compounds 1-5 are the first example of a mixed Ln-Fe MOF which consists of mixed sulfate anions and organic ligands. The magnetic analysis of 3 shows weak ferromagnetism between GdIII and FeIII ions. Furthermore, we also studied luminescence spectra and luminescence lifetimes of 1 and 4. The luminescence lifetimes of 1 and 4 are 0.98 ms, and 29.4 μs, respectively.

A mixture of Eu2O3 (0.1760 g, 0.5 mmol), Fe2(SO4)3 (0.1999 g, 0.5 mmol), H2L (0.1500 g, 1.0 mmol), dimethylamine solution (33%, 6 mL), and ethanol (3 mL) was stirred for 12 h in the air until all reagents dissolve, and then this solution was sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and kept at 170 °C for 7 days. Yellow block crystals were obtained (0.2063 g, yield of 39.78% based on Eu), which were washed with ethanol and dried at room temperature for 24 h. IR (cm–1): 3442 (w), 2783 (s), 1604 (s), 1466 (vs), 1405 (w), 1119 (w), 968 (w), 611 (s). Elemental analysis calc: C, 9.26, H, 2.41, N, 2.70%; found: C, 9.24, H, 2.20, N, 2.65%.

Synthesis of [(CH<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>NH]­[(CH<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>NH<sub>2</sub>]­[Dy<sub>2</sub>Fe­(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>4</sub>(L)]­·3H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>2</bold>)

Complex 2 as yellow block single crystals was prepared (0.2013 g, yield of 38.70% based on Dy) according to the same procedure as 1, except with Eu2O3 instead of Dy2O3 (0.1765g, 0.5 mmol). IR (cm–1): 3442 (w), 2781 (s), 1604 (s), 1467 (vs), 1407 (w), 1123 (w), 1050 (w), 970 (w), 614 (s). Elemental analysis calc: C, 9.07, H, 2.36, N, 2.65%; found: C, 9.01, H, 2.32, N, 2.61%.

Synthesis of [(CH<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>NH]­[(CH<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>NH<sub>2</sub>]­[Gd<sub>2</sub>Fe (SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>4</sub>(L)]­·3H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>3</bold>)

Complex 3 as yellow block single crystals was prepared (0.2027 g, yield of 38.67% based on Gd) according to the same procedure as 1 by replacing Eu2O3 with Gd2O3. IR (cm–1): 3417 (w), 2780 (s), 1600 (s), 1469 (vs), 1408 (w), 1123 (w), 1047 (w), 963 (w), 611 (s). Elemental analysis calc: C, 9.17, H, 2.40, N, 2.67%; found: C, 9.14, H, 2.34, N, 2.64%.

Synthesis of [(CH<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>NH]­[(CH<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>NH<sub>2</sub>]­[Sm<sub>2</sub>Fe (SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>4</sub>(L)]­·3H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>4</bold>)

Complex 4 as yellow block single crystals was prepared (0.2058 g, yield of 39.72% based on Sm) according to the same procedure as 1 by replacing Eu2O3 with Sm2O3. IR (cm–1): 3443 (w), 2786 (s), 1603 (s), 1467 (vs), 1405 (w), 1116 (w), 1047 (w), 963 (w), 611 (s). Elemental analysis calc: C, 9.26, H, 2.22, N, 2.70%; found: C, 9.20, H, 2.14, N, 2.67%.

Synthesis of [(CH<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>NH]­[(CH<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>NH<sub>2</sub>]­[Er<sub>2</sub>Fe­(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>4</sub>(L)]­·3H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>5</bold>)

Complex 5 as yellow block single crystals was prepared (0.2084 g, yield of 39.73% based on Er) according to the same procedure as 1 by replacing Eu2O3 with Er2O3. IR (cm–1): 3440 (w), 2783 (s), 1605 (s), 1466 (vs), 1410 (w), 1127 (w), 1045 (w), 965 (w), 613 (s). Elemental analysis calc: C, 9.15, H, 2.19, N, 2.67%; found: C, 9.10, H, 2.14, N, 2.61%.

The TG analysis experiments were performed under N2 atmosphere in the range of 25–900 °C. Thermal analysis shows that the 1–5 are analogous in Figures S11–S15. Take 1 as an example. As shown in Figure S11, there is no obvious weight loss from room temperature to about 110 °C. Complex 1 exhibits an apparent weight loss of 12.79% from 110 to 320 °C, matching with the calculated value of releasing one protonated dimethylamine, a free dimethylamine, and three lattice water molecules (calcd 13.96%). As the temperature reaches 400 °C, the second weight loss is attributed to the decomposition of ligand [L]2–. Further heating above 480 °C gives rise to the collapse of the framework. The final residual weight was 41.41% corresponding to a mixture of Eu2O3 and Fe2O3 (calc. 41.62%).

Luminescence Property

The luminescent behavior of Ln-based compounds has attracted increasing interest due to the high color purity and technological applications in light-emitting diodes, lasers, plasma displays, and sensory probes and optical amplifiers, etc. Because good shielding of the 4f electrons by the outer 5s and 5p electrons leads to well-defined absorption and emission bands, Ln ions still keep their atomic properties upon complex formation. Generally speaking, the f–f transitions are spin- and parity-forbidden; therefore, the luminescence of Ln-based compounds is normally generated through the “antenna effect”. As a result, the luminescence properties of 1 and 4 in the solid-state have been measured at room temperature. As shown in , excitation of 1 at 396 nm exhibits five groups of characteristic emission bands at 579, 594, 616, 655, and 703 nm, which are respectively attributed to 5D0 → 7F0, 5D0 → 7F1, 5D0 → 7F2, 5D0 → 7F3, and 5D0 → 7F4 transitions of EuIII ions. The existence of the 5D0 → 7F0 (579 nm) symmetry-forbidden transition emission spectrum illustrates that Eu3+ is in the presence of a non-centrosymmetric coordination environment. As we know, the magnetic dipole transition 5D0 → 7F1 is insensitive and hardly varies with the coordination environment, whereas the electric dipole transition 5D0 → 7F2 is a hypersensitive transition, whose intensity is very sensitive and apt to be influenced by the host environment. From the figure, we can clearly see that 5D0→ 7F2 (the electric dipole transition emission peak) is significantly stronger than the 5D0 → 7F1, which also indicates that Eu3+ has the lower symmetric coordination environment. The dynamics of the Eu3+ PL (photoluminescence) was measured at room temperature (). The luminescence decay was successfully fitted by ways of a single exponential law (square correlation factor R 2 > 0.99). From the decay curve of 5D0 → 7F2 from Eu3+ in 1 under 395 nm excitation, the decay lifetime was determined to be 0.98 ms, which is significantly longer than the values obtained for reported Eu3+ coordination polymers in the solid state at room and can be attributed to the sensitization of Fe3+. As shown in Figure 16, complex 4 displays the characteristic emissions of the SmIII ion at 563, 598, 644, and 705 nm, which correspond to the 4G5/2 → 6HJ (J = 5/2, 7/2, 9/2, 11/2) transitions. The dynamics of the Sm3+ PL is shown in Figure S17. The luminescence decay was successfully fitted by ways of a single exponential law (square correlation factor R 2 > 0.99). From the decay curve of 4G5/2 → 6H9/2 from Sm3+ in 4 under 400 nm excitation, the decay lifetime was determined to be 29.4 μs.

Magnetic Properties

The temperature dependence of magnetic susceptibility of 2 and 3 was measured in the temperature range of 2–300 K with an applied magnetic field of 2000 Oe, while isothermal magnetization measurements as a function of the external magnetic field were performed up to 7 T at 1.8 K. The data obtained for complexes 2 and 3 are represented in and . For 2, the measured χM T value of 32.25 cm3 K mol–1 at 300 K agrees well with the value of 32.74 cm3 K mol–1 (for 2 Dy3+ ions with S = 5/2, 6H15/2, g = 4/3, and 1 Fe3+ with S = 5/2, g = 2.0). From 300 to 2 K, the χM T value decreases gradually to 15.77 cm3 K mol–1 at 2 K. The decrease of the χM T curve is attributed to a combination of intramolecular antiferromagnetic interactions and depopulation of Stark sublevels of the Dy3+ ions. The data in the range 2–300 K were fitted to the Curie–Weiss law, yielding C = 32.58 cm3 K mol–1 and θ = −3.23 K. In the case of complex 3, At 300 K, the χM T product is equal to 19.70 cm3 K mol–1, which is slightly smaller than the expected 20.15 cm3 K mol–1 value (for 2 Gd3+ ions with S = 7/2, g = 2 and 1 Fe3+ with S = 5/2, g = 2.0). As the temperature decreases, the χM T product of 3 increases slowly to about 50 K and then rapidly increases to the maximum of 33.69 cm3 K mol–1 at 5 K. This behavior demonstrates a ferromagnetic Fe–Ln interaction, as confirmed by the positive Weiss constant (C = 19.52 cm3 K mol–1 and θ = 4.67 K) in the range of 5–300 K. On further cooling, the χM T value decreases gradually to 26.34 cm3 K mol–1 at 2 K, which can be attributed to intermolecule antiferromagnetic interactions and the magnetic anisotropy of Fe and Ln atoms.

The field dependence of magnetization of compounds 2 and 3 is shown in Figures S18–S19. The magnetization at 1.8 K increases very fast below 1 T, and then slowly and linearly increases and is even saturated at 7 T. The maximum values of M are 14.13 NμB for 2 and 18.44 NμB for 3 at 7 T, which are smaller than the expected values for 2 ferromagnetically aligned Dy3+/Gd3+ ions and 1 Fe3+, suggesting the presence of significant anisotropy and/or low-lying excited states.

Thermal Analysis

The TG analysis experiments were performed under N2 atmosphere in the range of 25-900 °C. Thermal analysis shows that the 1-5 are analogous in Figures S11-S15. Take 1 as an example. As shown in Figure S11, there is no obvious weight loss from room temperature to about 110 °C. Complex 1 exhibits an apparent weight loss of 12.79% from 110 to 320 °C, matching with the calculated value of releasing one protonated dimethylamine, a free dimethylamine, and three lattice water molecules (calcd 13.96%). As the temperature reaches 400 °C, the second weight loss is attributed to the decomposition of ligand [L]2-. Further heating above 480 °C gives rise to the collapse of the framework. The final residual weight was 41.41% corresponding to a mixture of Eu2O3 and Fe2O3 (calc. 41.62%).

Luminescence Property

The luminescent behavior of Ln-based compounds has attracted increasing interest due to the high color purity and technological applications in light-emitting diodes, lasers, plasma displays, and sensory probes and optical amplifiers, etc. Because good shielding of the 4f electrons by the outer 5s and 5p electrons leads to well-defined absorption and emission bands, Ln ions still keep their atomic properties upon complex formation. The dynamics of the Sm3+ PL is shown in Figure S17. The luminescence decay was successfully fitted by ways of a single exponential law (square correlation factor R 2 > 0.99). From the decay curve of 4G5/2 → 6H9/2 from Sm3+ in 4 under 400 nm excitation, the decay lifetime was determined to be 29.4 μs.
